set.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to carefully put something down somewhere
set.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: She set the tray down on a table next to his bed.
Mark filled the pan and set it on the stove.
The workmen set the box down carefully on the floor.
Remove the mushrooms and set them aside.
set.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to put something into a surface
set.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: an alarm button set into the wall beside the door
be set into the wall/floor/ceiling etc
Gates should be hung on sturdy posts set well into the ground.
set.translation[0].definitions[1].note_b: Set is usually passive in this meaning
set.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: if a film, play, story etc is set in a particular place or period, the action takes place there or then
set.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: The novel is set in France.
All this romance is set against a backdrop of rural Irish life.
set.translation[0].definitions[2].note_b: Set is usually passive in this meaning
set.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to consider something in relation to other things
set.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: This debate should be set in an international context.
These casualty totals have to be set against the continuing growth in traffic.
set.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to establish a way of doing something that is then copied or regarded as good
set.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: It is important that parents set an example (=behave well).
The outcome of the case will set a legal precedent.
His photographs set the standard for landscapes.
Freud’s views on sexuality set the agenda for much of the century  (=people paid attention to the subjects he dealt with).
Art and literature flourished and this set the pattern for the whole of Europe.
The prime minister’s fierce speech set the tone for the rest of the conference.
set.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to make something start happening or to make someone start doing something
set.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: A study by military experts was immediately set in motion.
The chief executive will set in train the process of finding a successor.
Protesters set fire to two buses.
Her last remark has set me thinking.
The wind set the trees rustling.
set.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to decide and state when something will happen, how much something should cost, what should be done etc
set.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: International companies set the price of oil.
The government has still not set a date for the election.
high standards of hygiene set by the Department of Health
set.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to start doing something in a determined way, or to tell someone to start doing something
set.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: They set to work to paint the outside of the building.
set to work to do something
He’s about to set to work on a second book.
The boys were set to work collecting firewood.
Rocard set himself to reform public sector industry.
set.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: to move a switch on a machine, clock etc so that it will start or stop working at the time you want, or in the way you want
set.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: I set the oven to come on at 12.
Usually, the heating is set on ‘low’.
set.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: How long does it take for the glue to set?
set.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: when the sun sets, it moves down in the sky and disappears
set.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: if your face or mouth sets into a particular expression, you start to have an angry, sad, unfriendly etc expression
set.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: His mouth set into a rather grim line.
set.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: if a doctor sets a broken bone, he or she moves it into position so that the bone can grow together again
set.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: if a broken bone sets, it joins together again
set.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: to give a student in your class a piece of work to do
set.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: Mr Biggs has set us a 2,000-word essay.
set.translation[0].definitions[15].defin: to write the questions for an examination
set.translation[0].definitions[15].examp: The head teacher sets the questions for the English exam.
set.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: to arrange the words and letters of a book, newspaper etc so it is ready to be printed
set.translation[0].definitions[16].examp: In those days, books had to be set by hand.
set.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: to arrange someone’s hair while it is wet so that it has a particular style when it dries
set.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 5: to establish a way of doing something that is then copied or regarded as good
set.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: Parents should try to set a good example to their teenagers.
This legislation would set a most dangerous precedent.
That first day seemed to set the pattern for the following weeks.
The gloomy first chapter sets the tone for the rest of the novel.
They wanted to set the standard for software.
We are not attempting to set the agenda for other women’s groups.
With regard to industrialization, Britain set the pace in the first half of the nineteenth century.
set.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 7: to decide and state when something will happen, how much something should cost, what should be done etc
set.translation[0].note_box[1].sections[: No date has been set for the election.
The government has set new food quality standards for all school canteens.
Set strict limits on your spending.
set.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: a group of similar things that belong together or are related in some way
set.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: We face a new set of problems.
The older generation have a different set of values.
set.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: a television, or a piece of equipment for receiving radio signals
set.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: a place where a film or television programme is filmed
set.translation[1].definitions[2].exampl: Cruise met Kidman on the set of ‘Days of Thunder’.
set.translation[1].definitions[3].defini: the scenery, furniture etc used on a stage in a play or in the place where a film or television show is being made
set.translation[1].definitions[4].defini: one part of a game such as tennis or volleyball
set.translation[1].definitions[5].defini: a group of people who are similar in some way and spend time together socially
set.translation[1].definitions[5].exampl: a favourite meeting place of the smart set  (=rich and fashionable people)
Val got in with a wild set at college.
set.translation[1].definitions[6].defini: a performance by a singer, band, or disc jockey
set.translation[1].definitions[7].defini: a group of numbers, shapes etc in mathematics
set.translation[1].definitions[7].exampl: The set (x, y) has two members.
set.translation[1].definitions[8].defini: a group of children who are taught a particular school subject together because they have the same level of ability in that subject
set.translation[1].definitions[8].exampl: Adam’s in the top set for maths.
set.translation[1].definitions[9].defini: a small onion that you plant in order to grow bigger ones
set.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: being in the position that is mentioned
set.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: a medieval village set high on a hill
a big house set back from the road
set.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: used to say that something is in front of a particular background, especially in a way that is attractive
set.translation[2].definitions[1].exampl: a small town of white buildings, set against a background of hills
pink petals set against dark green foliage
set.translation[2].definitions[2].defini: a set amount, time etc is fixed and is never changed
set.translation[2].definitions[2].exampl: We were paid a set amount each week.
The evening meal is served at a set time.
Small children like a set routine.
set.translation[2].definitions[3].defini: someone who is set for something is ready for it
set.translation[2].definitions[3].exampl: Get set (=get ready) for a night of excitement.
On your marks, get set, go (=said to start a race).
Are you all set for the trip?
I was just set to go when the phone rang.
set.translation[2].definitions[4].exampl: People had very set ideas about how to bring up children.
Mark was 65 and rather set in his ways (=habits).
set.translation[2].definitions[5].defini: a set meal in a restaurant has a fixed price and a more limited choice than usual
set.translation[2].definitions[5].exampl: The hotel does a very good set menu.
set.translation[2].definitions[6].defini: if your face is set, it has a fixed expression on it, especially one that is angry, worried etc
set.translation[2].definitions[6].exampl: He stared at her, his face set.
Kate’s face was set in a grim expression.
‘Damn you, ’ he said through set teeth.
set.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: a way of buying and paying for goods on the Internet that allows the safe exchange of personal and financial information
set.translation[4].definitions[0].defini: to decide that something should happen on a particular date, cost a particular amount, be done in a particular way etc
set.translation[4].definitions[0].exampl: We haveset a deadline of 31 December for the receipt of bids.
The initialprice is set at $6 a share.
The OPEC agreementset aproduction ceiling (=limit) of 22.5 million barrels of oil a day.
set.translation[4].definitions[1].defini: to establish standards, aims etc for doing something
set.translation[4].definitions[1].exampl: The new Chief Executive will be under pressure to maintain the growth targets set by his predecessor.
Twenty-one computer companies met to set a standard for advanced computers.
set.translation[4].definitions[2].defini: to decide that someone should try to achieve something, especially something that needs a lot of effort
set.translation[4].definitions[2].exampl: The sales force was set a challenge — to find three good ideas for improving profit levels.
set.translation[5].definitions[0].defini: an amount, date etc that is fixed and cannot be changed
set.translation[5].definitions[0].exampl: These bonds pay investors a set sum on a set date in the future.
The subcontractor employs the workforce for aset wage.
